stream_context.summary: Kaze greyboxes/blocks out Course 13’s ice-castle platforming by prototyping a key gimmick: an ice hex platform that cracks (multi-step) and then dissolves, including particle/VFX to mask N64 rendering limitations. Along the way he reveals an imminent life change (a baby due in ~2 months) that will affect scheduling, and he accidentally fixes a long-standing pointer/misalignment bug that broke music/animations when entering a later area.
stream_context.significance_reason: Major personal milestone revealed (baby due soon) with direct implications for output cadence, plus a meaningful technical milestone: the course’s signature breakable-ice platform pipeline is prototyped and a previously persistent pointer/misalignment bug affecting later areas (music/animations stopping) appears to be fixed.

findings.summary: Kaze reveals he and Zeina are expecting a baby in roughly two months (a girl), and he implies this will reduce bandwidth for major commitments this year.
findings.quote: We’re going to have a kid in like two months.

findings.summary: He says he may not be able to do an “F3” this year because of the baby (suggesting a planned milestone/release/event may slip).

He’s waiting on “Eiza” who has a special plan for a release video—described as almost a documentary-style piece—before Kaze finalizes his own release video (he references this as being for “the slide”).
findings.quote: Eiza wanted it to make like a little bit of a documentary thing almost.

findings.summary: Course 13’s immediate production goal is “greyboxing” the platforming: model the modular platform pieces first, then build the fun traversal around them.

He prioritizes specific ice-castle platform gimmicks: crack-on-jump ice platforms, spinning ice shards, and wind gusts (with a potential need for architectural justification like windows). He also wants an “appearing path” mechanic inspired by Mario Galaxy’s light-path, originally associated with a Biobak idea.

He prototypes the crack-and-dissolve ice hex platform as a two-texture material/shader problem under N64 constraints (texture formats like I8/I4, prim color/alpha, dithering/threshold), iterating because what previews in Blender doesn’t match in-engine.

A major blocker was diagnosing why the dissolve wouldn’t animate: he repeatedly used the wrong variable/source (reading the wrong timer and even a display-list head pointer), causing random memory reads; once corrected, the platform finally fades/dissolves but still needs art/contrast tuning.
findings.quote: It was reading a random memory address instead of the timer.

findings.summary: While adding a new geo/material function (and fixing a crash caused by not returning properly), he believes he accidentally fixed a long-standing bug where RAM/ROM pointers could become misaligned—breaking music and animations when entering the second area of a level.
findings.quote: I think what I just did might randomly just fix that.

findings.summary: He debates whether to reintroduce a movement exploit that was removed as collateral damage from a bug fix (a setup that allowed a triple-jump style sequence). He’s conflicted because it feels like “cheese,” and considers balancing by removing kicks instead.
findings.quote: I’m 50-50 on whether I want it in the game.

findings.summary: To make the break feel better, he adds triangle shard particles and a mist/dust burst to hide harsh transitions, then tunes velocities/dispersion—questioning whether he’s becoming desensitized after staring at it too long.
findings.quote: I feel like I’ve looked at this for so long that anything that doesn’t look completely jarring at this point looks fine to me.

findings.summary: He notes practical pipeline friction: Fast64 material sorting/order issues, and that certain lighting workflows don’t work with MatStackFix (requiring prim/env color approaches rather than per-vertex light colors).

He describes a recurring workflow belief: sometimes it’s more time-efficient not to aggressively chase bugs immediately because later work may incidentally resolve them—though he acknowledges the counterargument.
findings.quote: Sometimes bugs just randomly get fixed like that.

biobak.summary: Kaze calls out a Biobak-suggested “appearing path” mechanic (a path that materializes as you approach) as something he definitely wants in Course 13, though it wasn’t planned into the castle layout yet.

Biobak provides/points to a Blender material file concept (iceeffect) that influences Kaze’s final direction: separating crack visibility control from dissolve/threshold behavior via prim alpha/dithering/texture alpha mixing.

zeina.summary: Kaze attributes the proposed baby name “Reina” (as a playful ‘rival’ naming scheme) to Zeina’s insistence, giving a small glimpse of their shared humor during development.
zeina.quote: Zeina was insisting on this name.

findings.summary: Kaze is waiting on Eiza’s plan for a documentary-like release video segment before making/finishing his own release video for a near-term deliverable (“the slide”).

key_stories.title: Baby due soon and the project’s cadence
key_stories.summary: In the middle of planning Course 13, Kaze reveals he and Zeina are expecting a baby girl in about two months. He immediately connects it to feasibility of major goals this year (e.g., an “F3”), implying upcoming constraints on time, energy, and release planning.
key_stories.challenge: Balancing an ambitious ROM-hack production schedule with a major impending family change.
key_stories.process: He communicates the timeline openly on stream, acknowledges plans that may not be realistic, and frames near-term work around discrete, shippable chunks (like greyboxing Course 13’s platform setpieces).
key_stories.outcome: A clear personal milestone enters the project timeline; expectations for major 2026 deliverables are implicitly adjusted.
key_stories.key_quote: I don’t know if I can do an F3 this year. Because I’m going to have a child releasing in a bit.

key_stories.title: Making the crack-and-dissolve ice hex platform work on real N64 rendering
key_stories.summary: Kaze spends the stream iterating on a signature Course 13 mechanic: an ice platform that cracks in steps and then disappears. The work exposes a recurring pain point of the project: effects that look correct in Blender previews can fail or look wrong in Mario 64’s actual rendering pipeline, forcing shader/material hacks and added VFX to sell the illusion.
key_stories.challenge: Create a readable, satisfying multi-step crack animation and a non-jarring disappearance on N64 constraints (limited texture formats, alpha behavior, dithering/threshold quirks, low contrast).
key_stories.process: He experiments with prim alpha versus threshold control, texture/alpha mixing for cracks vs base ice, adjusts contrast curves to slow the fade near the end, and adds triangle shards plus mist/dust to mask sudden transitions.
key_stories.outcome: The platform successfully cracks and dissolves in-engine, but readability (white cracks) and final look still need tuning; he ends the stream acknowledging he’s not yet happy with it.
key_stories.key_quote: It works in Blender, but not on Mario 64.

key_stories.title: Accidentally fixing the misaligned pointer bug that broke music/animations in a later area
key_stories.summary: While building a new geo/material function and chasing crashes, Kaze realizes he may have inadvertently resolved a long-standing, hard-to-reproduce issue where pointers would misalign. That bug had visible player-facing consequences: entering a second area could cause music and animations to stop working.
key_stories.challenge: A persistent low-level bug causing state/resource corruption when transitioning to another area.
key_stories.process: He adds new rendering/material logic, encounters an instant crash (from a missing return), corrects the implementation, and notices the prior misalignment behavior may be gone.
key_stories.outcome: He believes the pointer misalignment issue is fixed (unexpectedly), and notes it was a known pain point someone else (Arthur) wanted addressed.
key_stories.key_quote: No way that fixed the bug. What the fuck?

key_stories.title: Whether to keep movement exploits after bug fixes
key_stories.summary: A bug fix removes an unintended movement setup that enabled a triple-jump style sequence. Kaze pauses to question whether to restore it for fun/skill expression or leave it out as an exploit, considering tradeoffs like removing kicks to reduce cheese paths.
key_stories.challenge: Deciding how much ‘tech’ and exploitability belongs in a custom Mario 64 campaign without breaking intended platforming.
key_stories.process: He tests the behavior live, labels it not intended, asks chat for opinions, and explores compromise solutions (restore the setup but nerf kick-based cheese).
key_stories.outcome: No final decision is made; he remains conflicted and flags it as a design choice rather than a pure bug question.
key_stories.key_quote: It kind of feels like an exploit already.

open_questions.topic: How parenthood changes the project’s roadmap and Kaze’s daily workflow
open_questions.context: Kaze says a baby is due in ~2 months and he might not be able to do “F3” this year, implying changed capacity and priorities.
questions: What did you decide to de-scope or postpone once you knew the due date—was there a specific milestone that immediately became unrealistic?
How are you planning to protect development time once the baby arrives—shorter streams, fewer big refactors, more delegation, or a temporary pause?
In past crunches you could brute-force problems on stream; do you expect your design philosophy to change when time becomes more fragmented?

open_questions.topic: The intended ‘feel’ and readability of the cracking ice platform (cracks vs melt vs shatter)
open_questions.context: The platform currently reads more like melting than cracking; white cracks are hard to achieve because color and alpha are coupled, and Kaze leans on particles/mist to hide abrupt transitions.
questions: What visual reference are you actually aiming for—Mario Galaxy-style appearing surfaces, classic ‘ice shatter,’ or something new—and what would make you say it’s finally ‘right’?
What tradeoff did you end up accepting: crack readability, smooth dissolve, or performance/texture budget?
If you had unlimited tooling, what would the ideal version of this effect look like compared to what N64 constraints force you to do?

open_questions.topic: The accidental fix: what really caused the pointer misalignment bug?
open_questions.context: Kaze reports a long-standing issue (music/animations stopping in a later area) may have been fixed incidentally while implementing new geo/material code and fixing a crash.
questions: Can you walk me through what symptoms players would have seen when that misalignment bug triggered—and how often it happened?
What change do you think actually fixed it (and how did you verify it wasn’t just ‘not happening right now’)?
Did this bug influence how you designed multi-area levels (e.g., avoiding certain transitions or loading patterns) before it was fixed?

open_questions.topic: Design stance on ‘tech’ and exploits in Return to Yoshi’s Island movement
open_questions.context: A movement setup enabling a triple-jump sequence was removed by a bug fix; Kaze debates restoring it and possibly removing kicks to reduce cheese.
questions: Where do you draw the line between skill expression and sequence-breaking—what’s the philosophy for RYI compared to vanilla SM64 speed tech?
Do you design levels assuming players will discover advanced tech, or do you treat it as optional bonus routing?
If you keep certain exploits, do you ever build intentional ‘developer-approved’ shortcuts that feel like speed tech but are actually planned?

open_questions.topic: Eiza’s ‘documentary-like’ release video plan and how it fits the project’s public story
open_questions.context: Kaze says Eiza has a special plan for a documentary-ish segment and Kaze is waiting on that before making his release video for a near-term deliverable (“the slide”).
questions: Who is Eiza in the project’s orbit (editor, collaborator, friend), and what story were they trying to tell with a documentary-style release?
What is ‘the slide’ release in the broader rollout—an engine feature, a demo, a level teaser—and why does the video format matter here?
How do you want the public to understand this project: as a hack, a new game, or a behind-the-scenes engineering story?
